unnormalised: **Project Nilgiri Tahr Sees Promising Gains in Tamil Nadu**
normalised: **Project Nilgiri Tahr Sees Promising Gains in Tamil Nadu**

unnormalised: Chennai, Tamil Nadu – Recent surveys conducted by the Tamil Nadu Forest Department, in collaboration with the Wildlife Institute of India (WII), have revealed a significant increase in the population of the endangered Nilgiri Tahr in the Mukurthi National Park. This positive trend is attributed to the state government's ongoing "Project Nilgiri Tahr," launched last year with a budget of Rs. 10 Crores.
normalised: Chennai, Tamil Nadu – Recent surveys conducted by the Tamil Nadu Forest Department, in collaboration with the Wildlife Institute of India (W I I), have revealed a significant increase in the population of the endangered Nilgiri Tahr in the Mukurthi National Park. This positive trend is attributed to the state government's ongoing "Project Nilgiri Tahr," launched last year with a budget of rupees ten crore.

unnormalised: The project focuses on habitat improvement, anti-poaching measures, and community awareness programs. Forest officials have also implemented strict regulations to control tourism in sensitive areas during the breeding season, which typically coincides with the Onam festivities, a time when many locals visit the region.
normalised: The project focuses on habitat improvement, anti-poaching measures, and community awareness programs. Forest officials have also implemented strict regulations to control tourism in sensitive areas during the breeding season, which typically coincides with the Onam festivities, a time when many locals visit the region.

unnormalised: Dr. Priya Raman, a senior wildlife biologist at WII, commented that "The collaborative approach, involving both government agencies and local communities, has been instrumental in achieving these encouraging results. Sustained efforts are crucial to ensuring the long-term survival of this iconic species." Further surveys are planned for the upcoming months, covering an area of approximately 500 sq. km, to gain a more comprehensive understanding of the Tahr population dynamics. Protecting their natural habitat is a shared responsibility, as vital as enjoying a plate of biryani during festive occasions.
normalised: Doctor Priya Raman, a senior wildlife biologist at W I I, commented that "The collaborative approach, involving both government agencies and local communities, has been instrumental in achieving these encouraging results. Sustained efforts are crucial to ensuring the long-term survival of this iconic species." Further surveys are planned for the upcoming months, covering an area of approximately five hundred square kilometer, to gain a more comprehensive understanding of the Tahr population dynamics. Protecting their natural habitat is a shared responsibility, as vital as enjoying a plate of biryani during festive occasions.
